titleStmt.title: John Quincy Adams Diary Digital Project

div.p: 1. Saw Mr: De Grand, upon some business, concerning which he consulted me— Called at the Patriot Office, and left with Mr: Everett the Review of Ames’s Works N. 4.— At my Office a short time in the forenoon— Afternoon in my chambers writing— Evening walking with Mr: J. Gardner in the Mall.— I met this day in the Street Mr: William Penn, who called the day before yesterday and paid me a visit.

2. I called upon Mr: Penn, and took him with me to the Athenaeum, where I introduced him to Mr: Shaw— I was a very short time at my Office. In the afternoon I went with the Ladies and heard Mr: Alexander Townsend’s Oration to the Charitable Fire Society— Took tea afterwards at Mr: Welles’s the President; and pass’d the Evening, after walking with Mr: J. Gardner, at Mrs: S. A. Otis’s— Judge Cushing & his lady— Mr: Dexter & his family— Mrs: Sumner and her daughter, & Mr: Isaac Smith were there.

3. A Short time again this day at my office— Dined at Mr: William Gray’s in Summer-Street with a small company of Gentlemen— Mr: Hall— Mr: Brooks— Mr: Story— Mr: Emerson & Mr: Hazzen— Mr: Ives of Providence came in after dinner— Called with Hall at his house— Walk in the Evening with Gardner in the Mall.

4. Heard Mr: Emerson this morning, and Mr: Buckminster for him in the afternoon.— Remainder of the day principally applied in writing— Mr: John Gray— Mr: Minot and Miss Watson were here— Evening walk with Mr: Gardner— Catherine pass’d it, at Mr: Otis’s— I read the last Sermon in Massillon’s Petit Carême.— On the benediction of the Standards of the Regiment of Catinat.

5. An Escort of 600 horse, and about 200 persons in Carriages and Chaises, went from town this morning, and met Mr: Gore, on his way from Waltham, and accompanied him to the State House, to make his Speech— He was sworn into Office on Saturday— They pass’d by my house on their way, between 11. and 12. this morning— The Governor, and Lieutenant Governor Cobb were in Mr: Gore’s carriage and four— I called at the Athenaeum, at my own Office; at the Insurance Office, and spent the afternoon and Evening at home. Mr: De Grand pass’d it here with us.

6. George returned this morning from Quincy.— I was a few minutes at my own Office— A few more at the Patriot-Office, and at the Insurance Office— Afternoon in my chamber at home— I read the preface to Auger’s translation of Demosthenes— Heard George; and wrote— Evening walk with Mr: Gardner in the Mall.

7. The day spent much as yesterday.— Evening club at Mr: Cobb’s— About half the club there— Dr: Cushing Otis of Scituate, and Mr: Wendell Davis were there— Governor Gore made his speech this day to the Legislature— This Evening I received from Mrs: Knox a letter, requesting to be released from an engagement to take my next house, upon which she has put me to an expence of nearly an hundred dollars in repairs.

8. My brother was this day in town, and dined with us— In the afternoon he returned with his wife to Quincy— My day was spent as it has usually been for some weeks past— Partly at my Office, and chiefly in my own chamber— I begin to read Auger with some interest, and hope to make him useful to my pupils— Evening walk with Mr: Gardner in the Mall.

div.p: 9. I went to Cambridge, after making a light dinner, and attended the Declamation at 2. O’Clock— There were but two Speakers— At 3. I read my 17th: Lecture— Then walked home— Miss El: Otis, Miss Joy and her brother, and Miss C. Foster pass’d the Evening with us, and we had music— I continue reading Auger; and writing on subjects of less importance.

10. The review of Ames’s works, N. 6. was this day published— Here it will rest for the present— It has attracted very little notice. At Midnight when this morning commenced, we were all awaked, by a discharge of Cannon at the gun-house, on the renewal of Commerce with England— And about 2. in the morning, the news arrived in town, of the New British orders in Council of 26. April last.— This afternoon my brother came in for me from Quincy, and I went with him there— John was unwell with a cough, and some fever; so that I did not take him out— At which he was much disappointed— I attended at 12. O’Clock at Mr: W. Payne’s Office in State Street-Exchange-building, a meeting of the Middlesex Canal Directors— Coll: S. Bradford is nominated Sheriff of Suffolk County.

11. Heard Mr: Gray of Roxbury, for Mr: Whitney the whole day— Miss Hannah Adams, is on her annual visit at my father’s— Mr: Craft and Mr: Haskins with Mr: George Beale called early in the Evening— I pass’d much of the day in reading trash not worth being read, and the evening in conversation with my father.

12. Returned to Boston this morning in the Stage— Mr: T. Greenleaf junr: was with me— This was the first summer day we have had, and my thermometer stood at 88.— In the Evening Mr: W. Foster junr: and his wife, and Mr: Brimmer and his Sister were here.

13. I pass’d this forenoon at my Office, examining a question respecting forfeitures; and found room for further enquiry. Afternoon at home, reading Auger’s prefaces— John broke out this day with the meazles— Mr: T. Greenleaf junr: was here in the Evening—

14. My father came to town and attended the meeting of the agricultural Society— My Mother, and Mrs: Charles Adams came in with him— Mr: W. Gray called upon me to draw a petition for him to the District Judge, which I did. My father & Mother dined with us— I called at Mr: Gray’s, and got his signature to the Petition— And an order from the Judge for a hearing to-morrow Morning— Club this Evening at Judge Davis’s.

15. I attended before the District Judge, upon the Petition of Mr: Gray, for a remission of the forfeiture on the seizure of his vessel and Cargo; and went through the business— I received a letter from Mr: Bacon at Washington— Afternoon confined to the house, by the rain— I called in the Evening at Dr: Welsh’s, and pass’d an hour there— On my return home, I found Mr: Everett, with whom we had some music, and who supp’d with us.

div.p: 16. After passing the morning at home, I walk’d to Cambridge— Attended the Declamation at which there were only four Speakers. At 3. O’Clock I read my Lecture 18. And then walked home. I wrote untill dark at my Office, answering Mr: Bacon’s letter. Walk in the Evening, in the Mall, with Mr: J. Gardner.

17. Messrs: Story, D. Everett, A. H. Everett, Shaw, and F. Parkman, and my brother dined with us this day— They went away soon after dinner— But the day was given to this matter, and I find it always so— In the afternoon I could neither read nor write, with any profit— I read however something of Dr. Trumbull’s Manuscript History of the United States, which Dr: Morse has lent me, with a request that I would peruse, and freely remark upon it— Mrs: Adams this Evening was quite unwell.

18. Mrs: Adams quite sick all Night, and unwell all this day. Mr: De Grand came at 6. this Morning, and I went with him and George and bathed, at the sheds in Charles-Street— The water was low, and the weather cold— It rained while we were out, and continued almost the whole day through— Mr: De Grand returned and Breakfasted with us— Heard Mr: Emerson in the forenoon upon Superstition— I had heard the same Sermon before. After dinner as I was going out I met my neighbour Mr: Williams who asked me to go with him, and hear his Minister Mr: Holley, at the New South Church— I went— His Discourse was on 1. Gen: 26. God made man in his own image—which the preacher explained and qualified— He preaches in part extempore— They had a new choir of nearly an hundred singers— Evening at home— Read two Sermons of Massillon’s Careme— For Ash-Wednesday—the subject is Fasting—which he urges as a duty of the first importance— But he complains that it is not only violated but despised.— His arguments are the authority of the Church, and examples of holy characters, from the old Testament and Apocrypha— George learnt the latter half of Rousseau’s second Ode— I commenced in conversation with Mr: De Grand this morning some enquiries respecting the State of our manufactures, which if I am able (that is, if I have resolution and perseverance) I shall pursue.

19. I am unpacking the remaining boxes of my books, which have been in boxes ever since I left the Hague in 1797— They have on the whole suffered less damage than I had reason to apprehend— But some volumes of large works are missing— Mrs: Adams and Catherine went this afternoon out to Quincy, with Mrs: Pascal Smith, and her daughter— And returned late in the Evening home— After passing greater part of the day at my Office, I bathed alone, at the Charles-Street baths in the Evening, and walked an hour in the Mall.

20. Rose this morning before the Sun, and saw it rise, from the top of my house, as I had done at the last autumnal equinox and at the winter solstice— At the vernal equinox I was absent from home— My object was to mark the bearings of the Sun upon the horizon, from my house, and the extent of his northern and Southern declination— I pass’d some time at my Office— And employed the remainder of the day in arranging books and pamphlets— Evening walk in the Mall with J. Gardner.

21. Observed the Sun’s rising again from the top of my house; this being the day of the Summer Solstice.— Mr: De Grand called upon me and we bathed at the Charles-Street baths— George being troubled with a cough, I did not take him with us. I had bathed alone yesterday morning— My Mother came this day into town, and proceeded to Atkinson, where she intends staying untill next Monday— This afternoon I unpacked, and partly sorted my last box of books— Club this Evening at Judge Dawes’s, in his late father’s house, being the same day, and place where 32 years ago the first meeting of the club was held. Judge Dawes himself and Dr: Elliot, were the only two members now present who had then attended— It was now a full meeting, and Dr: Kirkland, introduced a gentleman from Albany, by the name of Breeze.

22. I had engaged to go with Mr: Odiorne this afternoon to see his manufacture of cut-nails at Malden— But as it rained we agreed to postpone the visit untill next week— I received an extraordinary letter from Mr: Eustis, the Secretary at War. Answered it in part— Mr: Monroe came to me, with a proposal to publish the Review of Ames’s works in a pamphlet— I doubted whether
the sale would be sufficient to defray their expence in the publication— He said they had a sufficient number engaged for that; and I agreed to give them a preface for the pamphlet— I bathed again this morning with Mr: De Grand— Mr: Charles Jackson, called on me to enquire whether I had lately seen Mr: J. Gardner, who he said, for some days had left his lodgings and was not to be found— I feel a deep concern for what I hear of this my old and uninterrupted friend. I pass’d the Evening altogether in writing.

div.p: 23. I was so much engaged in my chamber at home, that I could not reach my office, before I was called to go to Cambridge. I went however into State-Street and called upon Mr: Hall— Dr: Waterhouse called at my house, and told me, that the information I had given him of a vote of the Corporation, forbidding the attendance of the Students upon any other lectures on Natural History than those of Mr: Peck, he found was correct— It distresses him very much— I walk’d up to Cambridge— At 2. attended the declamation— The full number of Speakers appeared— At 3. I read my 19th: Lecture— Walked immediately afterwards into town— Wrote at my Office untill dusk— Mr: D. Everett called on me, but I was not prepared with my preface for him— Going home I met Mr: W. Gray, at the entrance of the Mall, and walk’d with him about half an hour.

24. Rose again with the Sun— I continue engaged in the arrangement of my books and papers; but sometimes doubt, whether I shall ever get through their confusion. Mr: De Grand came, and I went and bathed with him in Charles-Street— I was a very little time at my Office— My brother dined with us, and this Evening I went with him to Quincy— Took George with us— I was employed much of this morning, in viewing the ground at Mr: Foster’s wharf; where he has brought the actions for encroachment upon him. Saw at Mr: George Bartlett’s Store, a plan of the long wharf taken in the year 1708.

25. Heard Mr: Bowes Whitney, morning and afternoon— The former of his discourses was upon the forgiveness of injuries. I shewed my father Eustis’s letter to me; with which he was very much offended; he thought it contained an indirect insinuation that his object in his present publications was, to get me nominated to an Office;—and he advised me, if I should be nominated to St: Petersbourg, to refuse the appointment— He declared his determination to continue his publications, which I had supposed he meant to suspend for the present— Captain Beale was there in the Evening.

26. I returned to Boston this Morning with Mr: T. Greenleaf— My brother brought in George— I was at my Office— Wrote a Post-script to my letter to Eustis, and sent it— A number of hatters who are about to form a Company to establish a Manufacture of Hats called upon me, and employed me to draw up Articles for their Association.— In the afternoon I was engaged, investigating a case upon which I am to appear in the U.S. District Court— Evening walk in the Mall— On my return home, I found my mother and Louisa Smith, who had returned this day from Haverhill— Mr: W. Foster and his Lady, and Mr: De Grand were also here.

27. My Mother lodged here last Night, and dined with us this day— This afternoon she returned to Quincy— I finished last Evening my preface, and carried the title-page, and motto to Mr: D. Everett— At my Office and at the District Court, which commenced its Session this day. Mr: Watson, agreed to take my house next mine; from the 15th: of July— This afternoon Mr: Odiorne took me out in his Chaise to see his manufactory of cut-nails at Malden, five miles from Boston— He has one building with eight of his patent machines, which cut and head a nail by a single stroke; another building with three; where many more were intended, but which had failed for want of sufficient water; and a building now erecting where he expects to have twenty of the machines at work— The water is very scanty, and untill about two years since supplied only a single grist-mill; which he says the inhabitants of the place, complain of having lost— The machines are very ingenious, and not very complicated; but I am not versed enough in mechanics to understand all their operations— This embarrassment I have always found on visiting places where machinery is used— In the neighbourhood there is another manufactory, for fulling and dying woolens— On a very small scale— Mr: Odiorne told me there was an ingenious patent machine used there also— We returned early in the Evening to town— I stop’d a short time at my Office, untill dark— Then came home— Found Charlotte Welsh at my house— The Dr: came in afterwards— Mr: C. Foster, also passed an hour here— Mr: De Grand came this morning to go and bathe with me; but upon going out we found the tide would not suit.

28. Forenoon pass’d in attendance upon the United States District Court— And at my Office— Afternoon partly at home and then at my own Office with Mr: Jos: Hall— Evening with Catherine at Mr: R. Derby’s; where there was a small company of Ladies and Gentlemen— Mr: T. Pinckney junr: and his lady— Mr: & two Miss Izzard’s & a Mr: Bull from South Carolina were there— Coll: Humphreys— Mrs: H. G. Otis and her daughter & Mr: W. Foster’s family.

29. Attended all the forenoon in the District Court, which is occupied in the trial of Embargo cases.— Afternoon mostly lost, in searching for John who was missing— Weather warm to such excess that it disqualified me both from reading and writing— Mr: B. Austin brought me an Invitation to dine with the Bunker’s Hill Association the 4th: of July; to which I consented— I had also an invitation from the young Republicans, at the Exchange-Buildings, to visit them— I had intended to go with my family that day to Quincy; but cannot evade these invitations— Evening walk in the Mall, and at home hearing Music from the Ladies— Charles, our youngest child has the meazles severely, and is this day at the worst.

div.p: 30. A rainy Night was this day succeeded by a cold and blustering day— I was writing at home, all the morning, and walked to Cambridge— On the road I was overtaken by Dr: Waterhouse in his Chaise, and rode the remainder of the way with him— At 2. I attended the Declamation, and at 3. read my twentieth Lecture— Walked home, and pass’d a couple of hours after my return; at my Office— We were invited to a party at Mr: B. Joy’s; but sent an excuse— Mrs: W. Foster was here part of the Evening.

Day— A multitude of little occupations distracts my attention and my time to such a degree, that I can scarcely observe any of my intended purposes— I rise about the same hour as the late months, and sometimes earlier— But instead of reading with George, I pass my time untill Breakfast in arranging books and assorting pamphlets, or writing upon transient topics— I seldom get to my Office untill 11. or twelve O’Clock, and pass most of my afternoon’s at home. I have bathed several mornings during this month— I go little into Company abroad, but have frequent occasional visitors at home— George’s instruction and my own have almost entirely failed.
